ownPages.title: ScopeChain
ownPages.content: A stack data structure used to represent the scope of variables that are currently accessible. Pushing a new scope will allow the template to add variables with names of pre-existing variables without overriding the originals; to access the original variables you would pop the scope again.

ownPages.title: Hierarchy
ownPages.content: A data structure that represents the entire inheritance hierarchy of the current template and tracks which level in the hierarchy we are currently evaluating.

ownPages.title: EvaluationContextImpl
ownPages.content: An evaluation context will store all stateful data that is necessary for the evaluation of a template. Passing the entire state around will assist with thread safety.

ownPages.title: Scope
ownPages.content: A scope is a map of variables. A "local" scope ensures that the search for a particular variable will end at this scope whether or not it was found.

ownPages.title: PebbleTemplateImpl
ownPages.content: The actual implementation of a PebbleTemplate

ownPages.title: EvaluationOptions
ownPages.content: Evaluation options.

ownPages.title: PebbleTemplate
ownPages.content: A template object constructed by an instance of {@link com.mitchellbosecke.pebble.PebbleEngine}. A template by itself is stateless and can therefore be re-used over and over to provide different outputs depending on the variables that are provided at the time of evaluation.

ownPages.title: EvaluationContext
ownPages.content: Created by mitchell on 2016-11-13.

ownPages.title: CacheKey
ownPages.content: Key to be used in the cache

ownPages.title: SafeString
ownPages.content:
Wrap a string in this to mark the string as safe to ignore by the Escape extension.

Warning: The EscaperExtension will never escape a string that is wrapped with this class.

ownPages.title: EscaperNodeVisitorFactory
ownPages.content: Factory class for creating {@link EscaperNodeVisitor}.

ownPages.title: NodeVisitorFactory
ownPages.content:
The node visitor factory creates {@link NodeVisitor}s.

{@link Extension} can provide own implementation to provide their own {@link NodeVisitor}s.

ownPages.title: PrettyPrintNodeVisitorFactory
ownPages.content: Implementation of {@link NodeVisitorFactory} to create {@link PrettyPrintNodeVisitor}.

ownPages.title: AbstractNodeVisitor
ownPages.content: A base node visitor that can be extended for the sake of using it's navigational abilities.

ownPages.title: ExtensionRegistry
ownPages.content:
Storage for the extensions and the components retrieved from the various extensions.

Created by mitch_000 on 2015-11-28.

ownPages.title: NodeVisitor
ownPages.content:
Will visit all the nodes of the AST provided by the parser. The NodeVisitor is responsible for the navigating the tree, it can extend AbstractNodeVisitor for help with this.

A NodeVisitor can still use method overloading to visit expressions (it's just not required).

The implementor does not need to make sure that the implementation is thread-safe.

ownPages.title: ReverseFilter
ownPages.content: Revert the order of an input list

ownPages.title: MacroAndBlockRegistrantNodeVisitorFactory
ownPages.content: Implementation of {@link NodeVisitorFactory} to handle {@link MacroAndBlockRegistrantNodeVisitor}.

ownPages.title: DefinedTest
ownPages.content:
Implementation for the test function 'defined'.

Inversion of 'null' test function to provide better compatibility with the original twig version and JTwig.

ownPages.title: RangeFunction
ownPages.content: Range function to iterate over long or a string with a length of 1.

ownPages.title: FirstFilter
ownPages.content: Returns the first element of a collection

ownPages.title: LastFilter
ownPages.content: Returns the last element of a collection

ownPages.title: ReplaceFilter
ownPages.content: This class implements the 'replace' filter.

ownPages.title: RsortFilter
ownPages.content: Sort list items in the reverse order

ownPages.title: JoinFilter
ownPages.content: Concatenates all entries of a collection, optionally glued together with a particular character such as a comma.

ownPages.title: StringWriterSpecializedAdapter
ownPages.content: A ${@link SpecializedWriter} that wraps a ${@link StringWriter}. Directly write numbers into the underlying ${@link StringBuffer} and save String allocations (compared to ${@link java.io.Writer}).

ownPages.title: PooledSpecializedStringWriter
ownPages.content:
A ${@link SpecializedWriter} that's pooled in a ${@link ThreadLocal}. It's backed by a ${@link StringBuilder} so it's not threadsafe but doesn't involve synchronization. Beware that it has some limitations:

  • As it's backed by a ${@link ThreadLocal}, it might leak in environments where ClassLoaders are rebooted at runtime
  • It doesn't take any security measure against very large payloads that would cause underlying buffers to eat memory

ownPages.title: SpecializedWriter
ownPages.content: A special type to be implemented by ${@link java.io.Writer}s so Pebble can bypass ${@link Number}s String allocation and directly write primitives.

ownPages.title: ClasspathLoader
ownPages.content: Uses a classloader to find templates located on the classpath.

ownPages.title: DelegatingLoaderCacheKey
ownPages.content:
The delegating loader cache key is used as the cache key for {@link DelegatingLoader}.

The object stores all cache keys of all loaders. Those keys together builds the key for the delegating loader.

ownPages.title: StringLoader
ownPages.content: This loader is not intended to be used in a production system; it is primarily for testing and debugging. Many tags do not work when using this loader, such as "extends", "imports", "include".

ownPages.title: Loader
ownPages.content: Interface used to find templates for Pebble. Different implementations can use different techniques for finding templates such as looking on the classpath, looking in a database, using a servlet context, etc.

ownPages.title: FileLoader
ownPages.content: This loader searches for a file located anywhere on the filesystem. It uses java.io.File to perform the lookup.

ownPages.title: DelegatingLoader
ownPages.content: This loader will delegate control to a list of children loaders. This is the default implementation used by Pebble; it delegates to a classpath loader and a file loader to increase the chances of finding templates with varying setups.

ownPages.title: ServletLoader
ownPages.content: Loader that uses a servlet context to find templates.

ownPages.title: TemplateSource
ownPages.content: An implementation of CharSequence that is tuned to be used specifically by {@link LexerImpl}. It is possible to advance through the sequence without allocating a copy and it is possible to perform regex matches from the logical beginning of the remaining un-tokenized source. This class will also standardize newline characters from different architectures.

ownPages.title: LexerImpl
ownPages.content:
This class reads the template input and builds single items out of it.

This class is not thread safe.

ownPages.title: Syntax.Builder
ownPages.content: Helper class to create new instances of {@link Syntax}.

ownPages.title: Syntax
ownPages.content:
The syntax describes the different syntax parts of the Pebble language.

This object is immutable after the creation. This is to make sure the syntax cannot be changed during the execution.

ownPages.title: PebbleEngine.Builder
ownPages.content: A builder to configure and construct an instance of a PebbleEngine.

ownPages.title: PebbleEngine
ownPages.content: The main class used for compiling templates. The PebbleEngine is responsible for delegating responsibility to the lexer, parser, compiler, and template cache.

ownPages.title: TestInvocationExpression
ownPages.content: The right hand side to the test expression.

ownPages.title: ForNode
ownPages.content: Represents a "for" loop within the template.

ownPages.title: FromNode
ownPages.content:
From Node for

{% from "templateName" import macroName as alias %}

ownPages.title: RangeExpression
ownPages.content: Expression which implements the range function.

ownPages.title: RenderableNodeExpression
ownPages.content: This class wraps a {@link RenderableNode} into an expression. This is used by the filter TAG to apply a filter to large chunk of template which is contained within a renderable node.

ownPages.title: ConcatenateExpression
ownPages.content: Expression which implements the string concatenation.

ownPages.title: GetAttributeExpression
ownPages.content: Used to get an attribute from an object. It will look up attributes in the following order: map entry, array item, list item, get method, is method, has method, public method, public field.

ownPages.title: FilterInvocationExpression
ownPages.content: The right hand side to the filter expression.

ownPages.title: TextNode
ownPages.content: Represents static text in a template.

ownPages.title: CacheNode
ownPages.content: Node for the cache tag

ownPages.title: ParserOptions
ownPages.content: Parser options.

ownPages.title: StoppingCondition
ownPages.content: Implementations of this class are provided by the TokenParsers and handed to the main Parser. The main parser will parse some of the template until the stopping condition evaluates to true; at this point responsibility is transferred back to the TokenParser.

ownPages.title: ExpressionParser
ownPages.content: Parses expressions.

ownPages.title: OperatorUtils
ownPages.content:
This class acts as a sort of wrapper around Java's built in operators. This is necessary because Pebble treats all user provided variables as Objects even if they were originally primitives.

It's important that this class mimics the natural type conversion that Java will apply when performing operators. This can be found in section 5.6.2 of the Java 7 spec, under Binary Numeric Promotion.

ownPages.title: FutureWriter
ownPages.content:
A Writer that will wrap around the user-provided writer if the user also provided an ExecutorService to the main PebbleEngine. A FutureWriter is capable of handling Futures that will return a string.

It is not thread safe but that is okay. Each thread will have it's own writer, provided by the "parallel" node; i.e. they will never share writers.

ownPages.title: TypeUtils
ownPages.content: A small utility class to handle type operation.

ownPages.title: Pair
ownPages.content: A small utility class used to pair relevant objects together.

ownPages.title: PathUtils
ownPages.content: Utility class to handle relative paths.

ownPages.title: CacheTokenParser
ownPages.content: Token parser for the cache tag

ownPages.title: TokenParser
ownPages.content: A TokenParser is responsible for converting a stream of Tokens into a Node. A TokenParser often has to temporarily delegate responsibility to Pebble's main Parser or Pebble's ExpressionParser.

ownPages.title: FromTokenParser
ownPages.content:
From Token parser for

{% from "templateName" import macroName as alias %}

ownPages.title: FilterTokenParser
ownPages.content: Parses the "filter" tag. It has nothing to do with implementing normal filters.

ownPages.title: VerbatimTokenParser
ownPages.content: This is just a dummy class to point developers into the right direction; the verbatim tag had to be implemented directly into the lexer.

ownPages.title: Twig Compatibility
ownPages.content:
While Pebble was inspired by and generally has high compatibility with Twig, it is neither a complete nor an exact Twig implementation. There are features of Twig not supported by Pebble, there are features implemented in Pebble that are not supported by Twig, and some features might behave differently or use a different name or syntax. This page outlines the similarities and differences between Pebble and Twig.

Tags

Name Pebble Support Notes
autoescape full (docs)
block full (docs)
do none
embed none
extends full (docs)
filter full (docs)
flush none
for full (docs)
from full (docs)
if full (docs)
import full (docs)
include full (docs)
macro full (docs)
sandbox none
set full (docs)
spaceless none
use none
verbatim full (docs)
with none


Filters

Name Pebble Support Notes
abs full (docs)
batch none
capitalize full (docs)
convert_encoding none
date partial (docs)

This filter uses java.util.Date date formatting instead of PHP-style formatting.
date_modify none
default full (docs)
escape full (docs)
first full (docs)
format none
join none (docs)
json_encode none
keys none
last full (docs)
length full (docs)
lower full (docs)
merge none
nl2br none
number_format partial (docs)

Filter is named numberformat, and uses java.text.DecimalFormat formatting instead of PHP-style formatting.
raw full (docs)
replace full (docs)
reverse full (docs)
round none
slice full (docs)
sort full (docs)
split full (docs)
striptags none

trim full (docs)

url_encode partial (docs)

Filter is named urlencode.


Functions

Name Pebble Support Notes
attribute none

dump none

parent full (docs)
random none

Tests

Name Pebble Support Notes
constant none

divisible by none
empty full (docs)
even full (docs)

null full (docs)
